worker: Change graceful shutdown exit code

Since the shutdown is graceful, it makes sense to exit the process with
0 instead of the default value (currently 1). This will help process
management software (e.g. systemd) identify that the process exited
normally.

worker: Add graceful shutdown
Lint fix

worker: Add graceful shutdown

The graceful shutdown mechanism is only available for clustered
isntallations (e.g. devMode = true). This patch adds this option for
single core/signle thread processes as well.

Added hypernova-{aphrodite,styled-components} to README.md

Added hypernova-{aphrodite,styled-components} to README.md

As styling frameworks require specific setup on both client and server, using specific hypernova packages bundled together with all the styling frameworks setups improves hypernova users experience. This commit adds the packages to README.md to raise awareness that those exist.

Merge pull request #104 from airbnb/allow-logger-to-be-fully-injected

Allow a logger instance to be injected via the configuration

Allow a logger instance to be injected via the configuration

Currently, config can specify the options to be passed to the
constructed winston logger, but the specific transport is hard coded as
Console.  Some applications may wish to use other transports like Syslog
that are defined in other packages.

This change adds a config field, `loggerInstance`, that allows an
arbitrarily constructed logger to be passed in.  Really any object that
implements `log` should work, but this is intended for other winston
loggers.

Merge pull request #110 from airbnb/export-server-components

Export server components and allow listening on unix domain sockets
Export createApplication

Allow server.listen() arguments to be specified in configuration

Currently the configuration allows the host and port for the hypernova
server to be specified.  This change allows alternate listening
arrangements to be made, such as Unix domain sockets.  I like Unix
domain sockets.

Refactor hypernova server into subcomponents

The previous version is highly tied to a cluster-based
coordinator/worker model with some custom lifecycle management.  To
allow experimentation with other process/configuration management, it is
helpful to break up and export some of the components of the server
configuration.  This preserves the old interface, but allows an a la
carte option.

Merge pull request #107 from airbnb/execute-jobs-in-serial

Execute jobs in a batch in serial
Make processJob style configurable

Execute jobs in a batch in serial

Previously, we dispatched all jobs in a batch concurrently.  Rendering
jobs are compute bound, so we would not actually get parallel execution.
One effect of this is that timers for a job in plugins record a start
time from the point where all jobs are dispatched and record the end
time after all or most of the jobs have completely finished.  This
prevents us from being able to reliably tell how much latency a single
job contributes to the total latency (for instance, if job A takes
500ms, and job B and C each take 25ms, we may get results that would
indicate that jobs A, B, and C each spent 550ms executing, which is true
in a way, but unhelpful).

This change executes the jobs serially as a chain.

This should have no or minimal impact either way on actual response
time.

Merge pull request #93 from airbnb/josh_perez/b4192db9c158887823c8ff54ef9ae3a0

If invalid HTML is returned we reject with an err

If invalid HTML is returned we reject with an err

As a safeguard -- in case a developer pops out of the promise chain an
error happens and Hypernova is unable to catch it -- we can detect whether
something is "off" by inspecting `html`. The html returned should be a
string and exist. If it does not exist then that's a sign that something
is wrong and needs investigation. This should prevent errors from
slipping through the cracks.

Lets render return a promise for doing async work

Lets render return a promise for doing async work

This allows userland code to perform async actions and render the HTML
some time in the future. This opens up the possibility for doing async
rendering, data fetching prior to rendering, code splitting with
routing, etc.

Merge pull request #14 from airbnb/obj-for-data-attr

Lets one render the same component many times
Adds CHANGELOG
Updates documentation
Accepts object for data attributes and values
Adjusts documentation for load and fromScript

Lets one render the same component many times

Currently it's impossible to render the same component many times on the
page (you can only do this if your entry bundle has different keys) and
this is because the key you use to render a component must be unique.

This adds a data-hypernova-id attribute to server-rendered markup. The
value of this key is a generated unique id which will match the script
contents to the markup. This makes it possible to use the same component
on the page multiple times.

There are a few API changes:

- fromScript now takes a 3rd argument, an id. If it is present it queries
  for the matching key and id.

- load now returns an Array of { node, data } where previously it only
  returned { node, data }. If no elements were found while querying then
  the Array will be empty (previously it returned null).
Version 1.2.0

Merge pull request #34 from airbnb/make-error-handling-better

Fixes exception handling stack traces

Fixes exception handling stack traces

On some cases we pass/throw a non-error, we used to wrap that in an
Error and then serialize that new error. The problem with that approach
is that the stack trace would be completely lost.

Now we either include the original stack trace or no stack trace at all.
Because an incorrect stack trace is worse than no stack trace.

Merge pull request #35 from airbnb/base-context

Adds more flexibility for retrieving components

Pass more information to getComponent

This commit passes the `context` object as a 2nd arg to
getComponent. The point of this is so that getComponent can have access
to the props objects as well as any other future items we decide
to pass into context.

Merge pull request #32 from airbnb/relax-spec-reqs

Relaxes the spec requirements for afterResponse

Relaxes the spec requirements for afterResponse

Spec currently states that we should call String/toString on the
response after we've called afterResponse method. This change is to
relax those requirements enabling you to pass whatever type you'd like.
The end result should still be a string (of HTML ideally) but I don't
think we have to specify that.

Merge pull request #20 from airbnb/use-cjs

Switches to CJS in examples

Switches to CJS in examples

While ES modules are nice, they're currently not supported on latest
Node and they transpile a bit complicated on latest babel. In order to
simplify the example so one can get running as fast as possible we can
just switch over to using plain CommonJS modules which are simple enough
to understand.

Merge pull request #2 from airbnb/sample-app

[docs] Adding an example basic Rails application
[docs] how to run the example

8. Make sure the JS is at the bottom

If it is above the HTML then the node won't be found on the page and
your application won't client render, so lets put the scripts at the
bottom.

7. Teach Rails to render your view on the page

This commit adds a filter around the welcome_controller to let the
controller know that it is allowed to render Hypernova calls.

In the erb file we'll be calling `render_react_component` which calls
the service and renders the content in place.

6. Add the JavaScript file

This file is where the view will live and how we'll describe the view.
We're using React in this example so we'll create a basic "Hello World"
example here with an onClick handler to show that it also works on the
browser.

5. Add Hypernova package to Rails

We'll be adding the gem to Gemfile and then doing some initialization
and configuration for Hypernova.

We can also add the Hypernova development plugin which places helpful
error boxes on the page whenever Hypernova fails.

4. Setting up the Hypernova service

In the root folder we'll add a `hypernova.js` which can then be invoked
using `node`. This is the service that will server-render our JavaScript
components.

3. Setup browserify-rails

We will need some sort of CommonJS environment in rails in order for
NodeJS to server-render the components.

We've chosen to use `browserify-rails` for this example but you're free
to use whatever tool you'd like.

https://github.com/browserify-rails/browserify-rails

2. Generating a new route

Using `bin/rails generate controller welcome index` to generate a new
route.

1. Generated an example Rails (latest) application

This is just a `rails new simple` off a fresh install of rails.
